plausible_answers.text: limiting smoke exposure both in utero and after delivery, breastfeeding, and increased exposure to daycare or large families

qas.question: What methods are foolproof to prevent the flu?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The evidence for the effectiveness of measures to prevent<b5_0/><a0_0/> the development of asthma is weak. Some show promise including: <b6_0>limiting smoke exposure both in utero and after delivery, breastfeeding, and increased exposure to daycare or large families<b6_0/> but <a1_0><b7_0>none are well supported enough to be recommended for this indication<b7_0/><a1_0/>. Early pet exposure may be useful. Results from exposure to pets at other times are inconclusive and it is only recommended that pets be removed from the home if a person has allergic symptoms to said pet. Dietary restrictions during pregnancy or when breast feeding <a2_0>have not been found to be effective and thus are not recommended<a2_0/>. Reducing or eliminating compounds known to sensitive people from the work place may be effective. <b9_0>It is not clear<b9_0/> if annual influenza vaccinations effects the risk of exacerbations. Immunization; however, is recommended by <b8_0>the <a4_0>World Health Organization<b8_0/><a4_0/>. Smoking bans are <a3_0>effective in decreasing exacerbations of asthma<a3_0/>.
